'''Soko Richardson''' (December 8, 1939 – January 29, 2004) was an [[United States|American]] [[rhythm and blues]] [[drummer]]. His career spanned almost fifty years, during which he performed and recorded with seminal groups including [[John Mayall]]'s [[Bluesbreakers]] and the [[Ike Turner|The Ike & Tina Turner Revue]]. He is perhaps best known for his innovative [[arrangement]] of the [[Ike Turner|Ike]] and [[Tina Turner|Tina]] version of the [[Creedence Clearwater Revival]] song, "[[Proud Mary]]".<ref name="pressrelease">[http://lists.drizzle.com/pipermail/postcard2/20040130/021485.html Soko Richardson] press release from [http://www.pressnetwork.com pressnetwork.com] Fri Jan 30, 2004</ref><ref name="Paiste">[http://www.paiste.com/news/viewnews.php?newsid=4 Noted Soul Drummer Soko Richardson Dies] February, 2004</ref>

==Biography==
Born in [[New Iberia, Louisiana]], Richardson began his musical career at the age of 16, when he left home to tour the [[Southern United States|South]] with local bands. Shortly thereafter [[Ike Turner]], upon hearing Richardson play in [[Texas]], hired him to play with his band, Kings of Rhythm, and then later with The Ike & Tina Turner Revue. Richardson worked with Turner for the next ten years. In March 1971 Richardson's arrangement of the [[Creedence Clearwater Revival]] song, "[[Proud Mary]]" reached number four on the pop charts, and number five on the R&B charts. The song became a signature song for [[Tina Turner]], and won the band a Grammy for "Best R&B Vocal Performance By A Group."<ref name="pressrelease"/><ref name="rollingstone">''The Rolling Stone Encyclopedia of Rock & Roll'' (Revised edition, 2001) New York, Fireside/Simon & Schuster. pp.1010 ISBN 0-7432-0120-5</ref>

In 1971, Richardson joined [[John Mayall]]'s [[Bluesbreakers]], with whom he would tour and record for the next decade, playing with many of the diverse artists to whom Mayall gave a start.<ref name="bluesbreakers">[http://www.classicwebs.com/mayall.htm John Mayall's Bluesbreakers] accessed March 7, 2007</ref><ref name="mayalldiscography">[http://www.softshoe-slim.com/lists/m/mayall.html John Mayall Albums] accessed March 7, 2007</ref><ref name="rollingstone2">''The Rolling Stone Encyclopedia of Rock & Roll'' p.621</ref>

In the mid 1980s, Richardson joined [[Albert Collins]] and the Icebreakers, and became an influential member of the [[Chicago]] [[Chicago Blues|Blues]] scene. He helped earn the Icebreakers the [[Blues Music Award|WC Handy Award]] as Blues Band of The Year in 
1985.<ref name="pressrelease"/><ref name="Paiste"/>

Over the years Richardson recorded with many other artists, including [[Pee Wee Crayton]], [[Bobby Womack]] and [[English people|English]] [[guitarist]] [[Terry Reid]], with whom he was recording an album at the time of his death. Though limited by health problems in later years, he continued to perform and record, and sit in on [[jam session]]s with friends. He played his last gig a few weeks before his death, at a club with Reid.<ref name="pressrelease"/><ref name="Paiste"/>

Richardson died in the early hours of January 29, 2004, in his home in Los Angeles, from complications of
[[diabetes mellitus|diabetes]]. He was 64.<ref name="pressrelease"/><ref name="mayall">[http://www.johnmayall.com/news.html John Mayall Newsletter] accessed March 7, 2007</ref>
